subNodes.conversationText: Why--hello!  I am Sarah Bairnson, wife of Hamfast.  You can find him in Swordskeep.
Please excuse me.  I have things to do around the house.
Ah, welcome.  Do come in, do come in; you must be <FirstName>.  Hamfast told me to expect you.  I am Sarah.
Hmm.  Hamfast has told me that our would-be robbers are to now be our dinner guests.  I am less than pleased--

But he shrugged off my reservations and told me that adventurers have--unique ideas about right and wrong. So be it. Do know that I have counted the silverware, and should guess where to look if I find any of it missing.
[The door slams, and Hamfast and Danmar enter the house deep in conversation.]

Ah, <FirstName>!  I have not had so many guests in my home for some time.  It's too bad that the occasion is so gloomy.  But the fire here is warm, and Sarah's cooking good.  Let us eat, and then discuss our troubles.
That sounds like a fine idea.
Aye, there's a time for foes and fire, and a time for food and friends.
I do not think we have time.  Every minute could be precious.
If my many years as an adventurer taught me anything, it's that there's a time for fighting and a time for eating.  Foes and fire can wait; friends and food cannot.
I would agree; it is not courteous to refuse one's hosts when their table is so near--and not wise, when the food smells so heavenly!
You do me too much honor, Mistress Ianth.
Nay, an adventurer's hostess can never be too much honored.  My thanks for preparing this meal for us, Milady.
It does smell quite good in here.  I don't believe <FirstName> and I have had a decent meal for many months.
If we could dine on talk, Danmar, we'd be fat men!  I see that everyone else is ready.  Let's eat.

[Sarah sets the table with a savory pheasant, roasted with apples and glazed with buckwheat honey; squash; and a filling, crusty bread with ample cream and butter. You have not eaten so well for some time.]

[Danmar the innkeeper is a lively conversationalist, and when he is not downing the wine he provided for the meal, he is telling a story about his adventures along the Sword Coast, or a love affair he had with a girl of a prudish Waterdhavian noble house...]

[...Or a tale with fanciful incidents and convoluted plots, all, he claims, the accidents of his wanderlust-driven youth--a youth that seems as remote from his old age as the loud sea is from the lonely crag of Drawn Swords.]
[While the table is being cleared, you return to the kitchen to discuss the business at hand. Danmar clears his throat and turns to you quite suddenly--]
It takes more than a fire in the eye to fight one's way through a Zhentarim encampment and live to tell the tale.  It takes talent.
I would only be pretending modesty if I claimed I was unaware of my gifts.
What <he/she> means to say is that <he/she> is grateful for the observation.
[With a twinkle in his eye.] Nay, I think said what had to say clearly enough, Ianth.
You should know that I have dispatched one of the guards of the Sword and Dragon, the elf Revelian, to Corm Orp with the news of what you learned from the portfolio.

It may be that we are behind the times here, and that Corm Orp already knows of the loss of Darkhold--they have certainly noticed the Zhentarim spreading out through Sunset Vale.  I myself have known that there has been trouble in the Sunset Mountains for some time.  The orcs seem to be leaving them in droves--perhaps for the same reasons the Zhents left Darkhold.
I do hope that Revelian returns swiftly.  Sheela Peryroyl's church in Corm Orp may need me.
Revelian will return in a few days, I hope--perhaps earlier, perhaps later.  He is fleet of foot, but the road is likely choked with obstacles.
In the mean time, the documents you shared with me indicate one other Zhentarim camp in the immediate area.
Yes.  If you are willing, we would like you to attempt to infiltrate this one as well.
What is so special about this camp?

This camp represents the northernmost limit of the Zhentarim presence.  It is also, apparently, the location of a Banite general, one who would probably have more information regarding both why the Zhentilar left Darkhold and more specifics about future plans.  His name is Clydus--a wicked tyrant of a man, according to reports.
I just can't figure out why they are so dispersed!  They are strewn up and down the valley like leaves.
<color=blue> [Wisdom] Indeed, it seems as if having a number of different units deployed over one hundred miles leaves them extremely vulnerable to guerilla tactics like ours.</color>
It is a problem that makes no sense to me, either!
It is a puzzle to me as well.
They do not seem to be very well-organized.  If they were indeed driven from Darkhold, that is probably why.
Indeed--although it would still have made sense for them to move as one army.
Perhaps it is a ruse of some sort.
No, I do not think so.  It would be a very sloppy, pointless ruse.
I do know that the Zhentarim of Darkhold are a factious lot. Ever since the Dark Lord Bane was reborn, those who worship Cyric have been at odds with those who worship Bane.
Whoever forced them out almost certainly took advantage of the rivalry; Zhentil Keep must be gnawing at its own heart for not curbing the Cyricist presence in Darkhold sooner.

But this is all speculation. Perhaps your efforts, or the news Revelian brings back, will make all clear. [In a lower tone, and despite the fact that you are not in a public place.] You should also know that I have certain connections that are very interested in your progress...and in your talents.
I hope I haven't spoken prematurely.  I simply can't say more at the moment.  But I speak of friends.
The camp is in the Backlands, about twenty miles north of here.  The Backlands do not lend themselves as easily to subterfuge as the woods do, so infiltration might simply mean assault.

Regardless, the force is relatively small and weak, according to the documents.  General Clydus, however, might be difficult to kill--though killing him, I should say, would be a great boon to us.  Return to Hamfast once you have done this.
Very well.   We will seek out this general and whatever information we can.

Before you go, Brother Anselm, who could not make it this evening, told me that you should speak to him before leaving.  He has a small token of thanks to pass on to you, and some important words he said he must express to you in person.
Do you think Drawn Swords can offer us any reward for this task?
Yes, Danmar and I can put something together for you.  Know, though, that you are serving more than the people of Drawn Swords if you succeed in this.
Will you tell me nothing more of the "connections" you mentioned a moment ago?
No, no.  My wine turned traitor on me and loosened my tongue too soon.  You will know in time.
I hope that the effort will be worth it.
Ianth, Vroman, Gossam?  What do you think?
I have worked with Hamfast and Danmar to protect Drawn Swords for many months now.  I have no reservations about investigating this other camp.

[Gossam, who has been drinking heavily, makes his best effort to sound as serious as usual, but he stumbles over his words.] Hmm. Would it be wise for us to endanger ourselves, and potentially draw attention to Drawn Swords, by...infilstr...infitrating this camp? Hmm...Hells yes, I suppose.
[Slurring his words from the wine just a bit.] I...think you know my feeling on this, . I am surprised to find myself motivated by something greater than mere...[Struggling]...opportunity.
Your wine hasn't lost its potency, Danmar!
Well, Hamfast, wine--unlike men--, gains potency with age. But back to business.
Ianth, Vroman?  What do you think?
I am most pleased, my gracious host.
A pleasure to see you once more.
